Framework_Overview.vision: Create neuromorphic systems that seamlessly manage data flow from input through processing to reaction, with efficient transition from deliberative to reflexive processing, supported by contextually-relevant memory systems

Pillar 1: Biological Stimulus-Response.description: Full biological description of the pathway from sensory input to motor/internal response.

REQ-B1.1: Sensory Transduction & Encodin: Sub-1.1.1: Conclusive model of how raw sensory data is transduced into neural spikes
Sub-1.1.2: Proven mechanism for sensory feature extraction in early processing
Sub-1.1.3: Understanding of population coding for complex stimuli
Sub-1.1.4: Temporal dynamics of spike-timing in sensory encoding
REQ-B1.2: Neural Pathways & Integration: Sub-1.2.1: Detailed mapping of thalamic relay pathways for major senses
Sub-1.2.2: Model of multi-sensory integration in parietal cortex
Sub-1.2.3: Role of prefrontal cortex in top-down attentional gating
Sub-1.2.4: Feedback connections from higher to lower processing areas
REQ-B1.3: Decision & Action Selection: Sub-1.3.1: Conclusive model of evidence accumulation for decision-making
Sub-1.3.2: Role of Basal Ganglia loops in action selection
Sub-1.3.3: Pathway from Primary Motor Cortex to spinal cord
Sub-1.3.4: Inhibitory control mechanisms for action suppression

validation_criteria.model_validation: Match biological response times and patterns

Pillar 2: AI Stimulus-Response (Bridge).description: AI/SNN architecture emulating biological stimulus-response with similar efficiency.

REQ-A2.1: Neuromorphic Sensing & Encodin: Sub-2.1.1: Event-based sensor integration with SNNs
Sub-2.1.2: Efficient SNN algorithms for sparse feature extraction
Sub-2.1.3: Hardware-agnostic deployment on neuromorphic chips
Sub-2.1.4: Adaptive sampling based on information content
REQ-A2.2: Deep SNNs for Processing: Sub-2.2.1: Scalable training algorithms for deep SNNs
Sub-2.2.2: SNN architecture for multi-sensory fusion
Sub-2.2.4: Homeostatic plasticity for network stability
REQ-A2.3: Action Selection & Control: Sub-2.3.1: SNN model of evidence accumulation
Sub-2.3.2: Computational Basal Ganglia for action selection
Sub-2.3.3: Closed-loop SNN controller for actuators
Sub-2.3.4: Inhibitory gating for action suppression
REQ-A2.4: Metabolic Efficiency Validatio: Sub-2.4.1: Sparse coding efficiency metrics (< 10% activation)
Sub-2.4.2: Event-driven vs clock-driven comparison (>10x improvement)
Sub-2.4.4: Dynamic voltage/frequency scaling based on task demands

validation_criteria.baseline_comparison: Must exceed ANN baseline by 20% on efficiency

Pillar 3: Biological Skill Automatizatio.description: Biological transition from high-processing task to reflexive muscle memory.

REQ-B3.1: Initial Declarative Learning: Sub-3.1.1: Role of Hippocampus/PFC in initial motor task encoding
Sub-3.1.2: Mechanism of error-correction signals from cerebellum
Sub-3.1.3: Working memory maintenance during skill acquisition
REQ-B3.2: Procedural Consolidation: Sub-3.2.1: Pathway shift from cognitive to motor control
Sub-3.2.2: Striatum role in habit formation and chunking
Sub-3.2.3: Sleep spindles and REM in procedural memory
Sub-3.2.4: Dopaminergic reinforcement signals in skill consolidation
REQ-B3.3: Reflexive Execution: Sub-3.3.1: Neural signature of automatized skill
Sub-3.3.2: Cerebellar role in real-time tuning
Sub-3.3.3: Reduced prefrontal activation in expert performance
REQ-B3.4: Feedback Integration: Sub-3.4.3: Prediction error computation in cerebellum

validation_criteria.neural_markers: Shift from cortical to subcortical activation

Pillar 4: AI Skill Automatization (Bridg.description: Computational framework mimicking biological skill automatization.

REQ-A4.1: Model-Based Exploration: Sub-4.1.1: AI equivalent of declarative learning with world models
Sub-4.1.2: Architecture showing exploration to exploitation shift
REQ-A4.2: Policy Compilation: Sub-4.2.1: Compiling model-based to model-free policy
Sub-4.2.3: AI sleep consolidation equivalent (offline optimization)
Sub-4.2.4: Progressive network pruning during consolidation
REQ-A4.3: Efficient Execution: Sub-4.3.1: Reduced computational cost after learning (>90% reduction)
Sub-4.3.3: Hardware acceleration for compiled policies
REQ-A4.4: Feedback Integration from Resp: Sub-4.4.1: Error signal propagation from motor output
Sub-4.4.2: Credit assignment across temporal delays
Sub-4.4.4: Adaptive learning rate based on performance
REQ-A4.5: Transfer Learning & Generaliza: Sub-4.5.1: Cross-domain skill transfer metrics (>50% transfer efficiency)
Sub-4.5.3: Graceful degradation with component failure

quantitative_metrics.transfer_efficiency: > 50% reduction in learning time for related tasks

validation_criteria.human_comparison: Match human learning curves within 2x samples

Pillar 5: Biological Memory Systems.description: Biological memory encoding, storage, retrieval, and prioritization.

REQ-B5.1: Encoding & Consolidation: Sub-5.1.1: Hippocampal to neocortical consolidation model
Sub-5.1.3: Place and time cells in context encoding
Sub-5.1.4: Theta-gamma coupling in memory encoding
REQ-B5.2: Retrieval & Prioritization: Sub-5.2.2: Amygdala role in emotional prioritization
REQ-B5.3: Memory Types & Interactions: Sub-5.3.1: Working memory maintenance and manipulation

quantitative_metrics.encoding_rate: Single exposure for episodic, multiple for semantic

validation_criteria.computational_modeling: Match forgetting curves, serial position effects

Pillar 6: AI Memory Systems (Bridge).description: Computational memory architecture emulating biological systems.

REQ-A6.1: Encoding & Consolidation: Sub-6.1.1: Systems consolidation without catastrophic forgetting
Sub-6.1.4: Compression and abstraction during consolidation
REQ-A6.3: Memory-Guided Action Selection: Sub-6.3.1: Working memory integration with SNNs
Sub-6.3.2: Episodic memory retrieval for context-aware responses
Sub-6.3.3: Predictive coding using stored priors
REQ-A6.4: Memory Efficiency & Scaling: Sub-6.4.2: Active forgetting of irrelevant information
Sub-6.4.3: Memory indexing for rapid retrieval

validation_criteria.memory_tests: Match human performance on recognition, recall tasks
validation_criteria.efficiency_tests: Sub-linear growth in memory with task number

Pillar 7: System Integration & Orchestra.description: Cross-pillar communication, coordination, and emergent system behavior.

REQ-7.1: Cross-Pillar Communication Prot: Sub-7.1.2: Asynchronous message passing between modules
Sub-7.1.3: Priority-based routing for time-critical signals
Sub-7.1.4: Bandwidth allocation based on information content
REQ-7.2: Unified Temporal Coordination: Sub-7.2.3: Temporal credit assignment across modules
REQ-7.3: Global vs Local Optimization Ba: Sub-7.3.1: Hierarchical control with local autonomy
Sub-7.3.2: Conflict resolution between competing objectives
REQ-7.4: Emergent Behavior Validation: Sub-7.4.4: System-level robustness and fault tolerance
REQ-7.5: Development & Bootstrapping: Sub-7.5.1: Staged activation of pillars during development
Sub-7.5.2: Curriculum learning for system maturation
Sub-7.5.4: Critical periods for inter-pillar connectivity

quantitative_metrics.emergence_metrics: Novel behavior in >20% of test scenarios
quantitative_metrics.fault_tolerance: Maintain >70% performance with single pillar degradation

validation_criteria.emergence_tests: Novel solution discovery in unseen problems

primary_objectives: Match biological efficiency within 10x on energy
Achieve human-level performance on benchmark tasks
Demonstrate seamless automatization of learned skills
Show robust memory storage and retrieval at scale
validation_milestones: M3: Validate memory systems at scale
M4: Show emergent intelligence from integrated system
